de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.model.datastructure
Class Artefact

java.lang.Object
  de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.model.datastructure.Artefact
All Implemented Interfaces:
ObservableArtefact
public class Artefact
extends java.lang.Object
implements ObservableArtefact

Artefact is a wrapper for MetaClass objects. Here are those artefacts gathered at one place to which test data should be generated. Notice, at this point we only support two types of artefacts. That is, products and documents. Furthermore, we hold those sets in disjunct sets.

Each artefact is also an observable. Subjects observing artefacts get gets notified by the latest updates. This helps to get synchronized each time an update occurs.

Since:
Apr/07/09
Version:
0.1
Author:
Michael Munz

Method Detail

setArtefacts

public void setArtefacts(java.util.List<MetaClass> artefacts)
sets the artefacts at once and notifies the observers about changes.

Parameters:
artefacts - list of products

addArtefact

public void addArtefact(MetaClass artefact)
adds an artefact to the corresponding list and notifies observers about the data change. But before this is done, it has to be checked, if an element with that name is already in the collection. It's not allowed to put it in twice.

Parameters:
artefact - consists of a meta class.

getArtefact

public MetaClass getArtefact(java.lang.String name)
gets an specific meta class of products' artefact list. If an artefact could be found with the given name it is returned, otherwise null.

Parameters:
name - the name of an product artefact
Returns:
meta class with given name, or null

getArtefact

public MetaClass getArtefact(int index)
gets a specific meta class out of the product artefact data structure. If the structure is null, null is returned, otherwise the element at the desired index if the index is valid.

Parameters:
index - element at desired position
Returns:
meta class or null

hasArtefact

public final boolean hasArtefact(MetaClass mClass)
checks whether an meta class is already in the data structure of artefacts. We do this by the name of a class.

Parameters:
mClass - check meta class against product artfacts
Returns:
true, if and only if it exists already

public final boolean deleteArtefact(MetaClass mClass)
removes an artefact from the data structure. Because the data has changed after that operation, a notification is send out.

Parameters:

Returns:
true, if successfully deleted

removes an artefact from data structure. Because the data has changed after that operation, observers are notified about it.

Parameters:

Returns:
true, if successfully deleted

sets the type of artefacts for this collection. That means, there are only those kinds of types in it. Each type has it's own collection.

Parameters:
artefactType - type of artefacts

getArtefactType

public final ArtefactType getArtefactType()
gets the type of artefacts for this collection. For each type are one collection.

Returns:
artefact type

                                   ArtefactType type)
Description copied from interface: ObservableArtefact
Likewise, when an observer wants to un-register, we just take it off the list.

Specified by:
removeObserverArtefact in interface ObservableArtefact
Parameters:
observer - an object which doesn't want any notifications anymore.
type - the type of artefact to remove observer

notifyObserverArtefact

public void notifyObserverArtefact()
Description copied from interface: ObservableArtefact
Here's the fun part; this is where we tell all observers about the state. Because they are all Observers, we know they all implement update(), so we know how to notify them.

Specified by:
notifyObserverArtefact in interface ObservableArtefact
